texts.text-10-0: What is involved in Engineering Design?
texts.text-10-1: Engineering is a creative process where each new version of a design is tested and then modified, based on what has been learned up to that point.
texts.text-10-2: This process includes a number of components:
texts.text-10-3: Identifying the problem and defining criteria and constraints.
texts.text-10-4: Generating ideas for how to solve the problem.
texts.text-10-5: Engineers use research, brainstorming, and collaboration with others to come up with ideas for solutions and designs.
texts.text-10-6: Use criteria and constraints to evaluate possible design solutions to identify the one(s) that best address these parameters for the problem in context.
texts.text-10-8: Using data collected, the engineer analyzes how well prototypes meet the given criteria and constraints.
texts.text-10-9: Suggest or make improvements to prototypes to optimize the design.
texts.text-10-10: In the Science with Engineering Education (SEEd) Standards, specific engineering standards generally involve two types of tasks:
texts.text-10-11: If the standard includes the idea of designing, then the design process will contain components of defining the problem (along with identifying the criteria and constraints), developing many possible solutions, and optimizing a solution (e.g., determining a best solution for the situation based on the criteria and constraints, testing the solution, refining the solution).
texts.text-10-12: If the standard includes the idea of evaluating, then the design process will contain components of defining the problem (along with identifying the criteria and constraints) and optimizing a solution.
texts.text-10-13: The idea of developing many possible solutions is not included because various solutions will be provided.
texts.text-10-14: The idea of evaluating then means determining a best solution from the provided solutions for the situation based on meeting the criteria and constraints requirements.
texts.text-11-23:
CHAPTER 3-Cycling of Matter in Earth’s
                    Systems
texts.text-13-1: Strand 1: Characteristics and Interactions of Earth’s Systems
texts.text-13-9:
Earth’s major systems are the geosphere (solid and molten rock, soil, and sediments),
                        the hydrosphere (water and ice), the atmosphere (air), and the biosphere (living things,
                        including humans).
texts.text-13-10: These systems interact in multiple ways.
texts.text-13-11: Weathering and erosion are examples of interactions between Earth’s systems.
texts.text-13-12: Some interactions cause landslides, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions that impact humans and other organisms.
texts.text-13-13:
Humans cannot eliminate natural hazards; solutions can be designed to reduce their
                        impact.
texts.text-13-8: Image by Julius Silver, pixabay.com, CC0
texts.text-15-2: In the Pacific Ocean there is a pathway of active volcanoes with frequent earthquakes, called the Ring of Fire.
texts.text-15-4: Active Volcanoes, Plate Tectonics, and the "Ring of Fire"
texts.text-15-7: 1. What are you observing about this phenomenon?
texts.text-15-8: 2. What are you wondering about this phenomenon?
texts.text-16-1: What patterns do you see in the location of the active volcanoes?
texts.text-16-3: 2. Where do you see the least volcanoes?
texts.text-16-5: 3. What patterns do you see in the location of the active volcanoes?
texts.text-17-1: Analyze and interpret data to describe patterns of Earth’s features.
texts.text-17-2:
Emphasize most earthquakes and volcanoes occur in bands that are often along the boundaries between
                continents and oceans while major mountain chains may be found inside continents or near their edges.
texts.text-17-3:
Examples of data could include maps showing locations of mountains on continents and the ocean floor or
                the locations of volcanoes and earthquakes.
texts.text-17-5:
In this chapter, you will be looking at different patterns we see in
                Earth’s Features.
texts.text-17-8:
Volcanoes are openings in the Earth’s crust that allow hot, melted rock
                (magma), ash, and gases to erupt outward.
texts.text-17-9: Volcanoes change the Earth’s surface in a short period of time.
texts.text-17-10: More than half of Earth’s surface is made up of volcanic rock.
texts.text-17-11:
Volcanoes are evidence that we live on an active, changing
                planet.
texts.text-17-12: Do you know how a volcano forms?
texts.text-17-13: Far below Earth’s surface, temperatures are hot enough to melt rock.
texts.text-17-14: The melted rock comes out of cracks in the Earth’s crust, resulting in a volcano.
texts.text-17-15: Some eruptions pour out rivers of lava while other volcanoes have larger eruptions.
texts.text-17-16: Volcanoes can erupt underwater, forming huge ranges of volcanic mountains on the ocean floor.
texts.text-17-18: Most earthquakes and volcanic eruptions take place along the edges of the Pacific Ocean.
texts.text-17-19: The Earth’s crust is broken up into a series of massive sections called plates.
texts.text-17-20: The movements of these plates can account for noticeable changes to the Earth, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and the building of mountains.
texts.text-18-0: The many volcanoes and earthquakes along the Ring of Fire are caused by the amount of movement of tectonic plates in the area.
texts.text-18-1: Along the Ring of Fire, plates overlap.
texts.text-18-2: The magma near Earth’s surface creates volcanic activity.
texts.text-18-3: The border between the Pacific and North American Plates (Phenomenon image) is a transform boundary, where plates move sideways past one another.
texts.text-18-4: This type of boundary generates a large number of earthquakes as tension in Earth’s crust builds up and is released.
texts.text-18-17: Pacific Ring of Fire by Gringer, public domain
texts.text-18-5: Plates can also move away from each other within a continent.
texts.text-18-7: When this happens, the crust thins, breaks, and then splits apart.
texts.text-18-9:
Earthquakes are waves of energy that pass through Earth caused by a sudden
                shift of tectonic plates along fault lines, a long crack in the surface of the Earth.
texts.text-18-10: Earthquakes can cause sudden changes that alter the Earth’s landscape dramatically.
texts.text-18-11: Tremendous forces under Earth’s surface build up pressure, which is released in waves along a fault.
texts.text-18-12: Portions of Earth’s crust move, creating waves.
texts.text-18-13: Some of the waves are surface waves because they travel along the surface of the Earth.
texts.text-18-14: Other waves, called body waves, travel through the Earth’s interior.
texts.text-18-15: In an earthquake, body waves are responsible for the sharp jolts.
texts.text-18-16: Surface waves are responsible for the
texts.text-19-0: Rolling motions that cause most of the damage.
texts.text-19-1: Earthquakes can create landforms on the Earth’s surface.
texts.text-19-2: Mountains can form during an earthquake as the edges of the tectonic plates push together.
texts.text-19-3: During an earthquake, a fault may slip deep underground and leave no evidence on the surface that an earthquake has occurred.
texts.text-19-4: Earthquakes in the ocean may cause a tsunami, a large ocean wave.
texts.text-19-6:
In the oceans, plates move apart at mid-ocean ridges, causing volcanoes, creating openings 
                        for lava to rise upward, erupt, and cool.
texts.text-19-7:
As more lava erupts and pushes the original seafloor outward, the seafloor spreads and 
                        forms new oceanic crust.
texts.text-19-8: This is why there is a mountain range running through the oceans.
texts.text-19-9: The plates pulling apart cause earthquakes.
texts.text-19-10: Most mid-ocean ridges are located deep below the sea.
texts.text-19-11: The island of Iceland sits right on the Mid-Atlantic ridge.
texts.text-19-12: Mid Atlantic Ridge by Mangwanani, public domain
texts.text-19-13: The rift valley in Iceland is part of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
texts.text-20-2: Image by USGS, source; public domain
texts.text-20-4:
The dots represent active volcanoes. What do you notice about the
                        location of most volcanoes shown?
texts.text-20-6: The dark lines represent plate boundaries.
texts.text-20-7: What do we know about plate boundaries and earthquakes?
texts.text-20-8: Based on what you know about volcanoes and earthquakes,
texts.text-20-9:
what predictions can you make about changes to Earth’s surface in the
                        future?
texts.text-21-1: Describe two patterns of change to Earth’s features and how they occur.
texts.text-23-2: Most of the water found on the Earth is saltwater, not freshwater.
texts.text-23-16: Most of the water on Earth is saltwater (97%), and only a little is freshwater (3%).
texts.text-23-19: 1. What are you observing about this phenomenon?
texts.text-23-20: 2. What are you wondering about this phenomenon?
texts.text-24-1:
1. The image above shows how water is distributed on
                        Earth. How much water on Earth is salt water (saline water)?
texts.text-24-2: 2. How much water on Earth is surface water (lakes, swamps, or rivers)?
texts.text-24-3: 3. What do you find surprising about this data?
texts.text-25-1:
Use mathematics and computational thinking to compare the
                quantity of saltwater and freshwater in various reservoirs to provide evidence for the distribution of
                water on Earth.
texts.text-25-2:
Emphasize reservoirs such as oceans, lakes, rivers, glaciers,
                groundwater, and polar ice caps.
texts.text-25-5:
In this section, focus on comparing the quantity of saltwater with
                freshwater found on the Earth.
texts.text-25-3:
Examples of using mathematics and computational thinking could include
                measuring, estimating, graphing, or finding percentages of quantities.
texts.text-25-8: above the Earth in the air and clouds (atmosphere),
texts.text-25-9: on the surface of the Earth in rivers, oceans, ice (hydrosphere),
texts.text-26-0: Here is a chart showing the distribution of water on Earth.
texts.text-26-1: In the first column, notice that 2.5% of Earth's water is freshwater - the amount needed for life to survive.
texts.text-26-2: The middle column shows the breakdown of freshwater. Almost all of it is found in ice and in the ground. Only a little more than 1.2% of all freshwater is surface water, which provides most of life's needs.
texts.text-26-3: The right column shows the breakdown of surface freshwater. Most of the surface freshwater is found in ice, and another 20.9% is found in lakes.
texts.text-26-4: Rivers make up 0.49% of surface freshwater.
texts.text-26-5: Although rivers account for only a small amount of freshwater, rivers are the source of most usable water.
texts.text-26-23: Source: Igor Shiklomanov’s chapter “World fresh water resources” in Peter H. Gleick (editor), 1993, Water in Crisis: A Guide to the World’s Fresh Water Resources. (Numbers are rounded).
texts.text-26-24:
How Much Water is There On, In, and Above the
            Earth?
texts.text-26-25:
The Earth is a watery place. But just how much water exists on our
                planet?
texts.text-26-26:
About 71 percent of the Earth's surface is covered with water, and the oceans hold about 96 percent of all Earth's
                water.
texts.text-26-27:
Water also exists in the atmosphere, ground, and in the bodies of living organisms. Understanding the distribution of water helps us appreciate the importance of
                conservation and sustainable use.
texts.text-27-0:
air (as water vapor), rivers and lakes, icecaps and glaciers, the ground
                (as soil moisture and in aquifers).
texts.text-27-2:
Even though you may only notice water on the Earth's surface, more
                freshwater is stored in the ground than there is in liquid form on the surface.
texts.text-27-3:
In fact, some of the water you see flowing in rivers comes from water
                seeping into Earth's surface to become groundwater.
texts.text-27-4:
Water from precipitation continually seeps into the ground to fill
                aquifers (underground reservoirs),
texts.text-27-5:
while at the same time water in the ground continually fills rivers
                through seepage.
texts.text-27-6: Humans make use of both surface water and groundwater.
texts.text-27-7: In the United States in 2010, we used about 275 billion gallons (1,041 billion liters) of surface water per day
texts.text-27-8: and about 79.3 billion gallons (300.2 billion liters) of groundwater per day.
texts.text-27-9: Although surface water is used more often to supply drinking water and to irrigate crops,
texts.text-27-10: groundwater is vital because it fills rivers and lakes and provides water for people in places where water is scarce,
texts.text-27-11: such as in desert towns of the western United States.
texts.text-28-21: Most of the water on Earth is saltwater (97%), and only a little is freshwater (3%).
texts.text-28-22: Image by Mariana Ruiz Villarreal (LadyofHats) for the CK-12 Foundation, CC BY-NC 3.0
texts.text-28-24: 1. List three places where freshwater is found on Earth.
texts.text-28-25: 2. What water resources contribute to Earth’s surface water?
texts.text-29-1:
Draw a bar
                    graph to show salt water on Earth compared to freshwater on Earth.
texts.img-13-2: A volcanic island with visible smoke and steam rising, demonstrating interactions between Earth's geosphere and atmosphere.
texts.img-15-2: A map illustrating active volcanoes and tectonic plates, highlighting the "Ring of Fire" in the Pacific Ocean.
texts.img-18-2: A map illustrating the Pacific Ring of Fire, displaying tectonic plate boundaries and volcanic activity zones around the Pacific Ocean.
texts.img-19-2: A rift valley covered in snow at the Mid-Atlantic Ridge in Iceland.
texts.img-20-2: Map showing active volcanoes along tectonic plate boundaries, highlighting the "Ring of Fire."
texts.img-23-2: Diagram showing Earth's water distribution: 97% saltwater (oceans) and 3% freshwater, with breakdown of freshwater sources.
texts.img-25-2: A droplet of water creating ripples on a water surface.
texts.img-26-2: A chart illustrating the distribution of Earth's water, with 96.5% in oceans, 2.5% as freshwater, and the remainder as other saline water. Freshwater is mostly in glaciers and ice caps (68.7%), with ground ice, permafrost, lakes, rivers, and living organisms accounting for smaller amounts.
texts.img-28-2: Diagram showing Earth's water distribution: 97% saltwater in oceans and 3% freshwater, mostly in icecaps and glaciers, with smaller portions in ground water and surface water.
texts.sectioneli5-10-0: Engineering design is like building and fixing a toy. First, you figure out what's wrong with the toy or what you want it to do better. Then you think of many cool ideas on how to fix or improve it, maybe by talking with your friends. After that, you pick the best idea based on what you can actually do. Next, you build a model or a 'pretend' version of your toy. You test it to see how well it works. Finally, you make it better if you find any problems. This is how engineers make things work better step by step.
texts.sectioneli5-10-1:
In engineering, there are rules called standards that help make things work well. There are two big things these rules focus on:

1. **Designing**: This is like drawing a plan for a new toy by first figuring out what the toy should do (like bouncing high). Then you think of lots of ways it could be made, test the best one, and make it even better.

2. **Evaluating**: This is like having a bunch of different toys already made, and you have to choose the best one. You check if they all do what they're supposed to do and pick the best one based on those rules.

These steps help engineers create and improve things in a smart way!
texts.sectioneli5-11-0: This book is like a map of cool science stuff! It talks about Earth's systems, like patterns and water, and how things like wind can change rocks. It also explains tiny things we can't see, how different things mix together, and how we can keep nature balanced. Finally, it shows how plants grow, what happens when we eat, and how everything moves and stays connected.
texts.sectioneli5-13-0: Imagine the Earth like a super busy playground where four groups play together. There's the geosphere (rocks and land), hydrosphere (water and ice), atmosphere (all the air), and biosphere (plants, animals, and people). These groups like to mix and sometimes change things around, like how weathering and erosion shape the land. Sometimes they bump into each other, causing big changes like landslides or volcanoes. Even though we can't stop these natural events, we can find ways to stay safe and keep them from hurting us too much.
texts.sectioneli5-13-1: Earth is like a big, busy playground with different parts playing together. Imagine the ground you walk on (geosphere), the water you drink (hydrosphere), the air you breathe (atmosphere), and all the plants and animals (biosphere) are the friends in this playground. These parts talk and play with each other. For example, rain (part of the atmosphere) can wear away rocks (geosphere) over time, which is called weathering. Sometimes, these interactions can cause big events like volcanoes, which is like a giant mountain popping its top! We can't stop these big events, but we can find ways to keep safe, just like finding a shelter when it's raining.
texts.sectioneli5-15-0: Imagine a path around the edges of the Pacific Ocean that is very special because it has a lot of fiery mountains called volcanoes. These volcanoes are active, meaning they can erupt and send out hot lava. This special path is called the "Ring of Fire" because it has so many volcanoes, and it often feels shaky due to lots of little earth movements called earthquakes. It's like the Earth is doing a little dance right here!
texts.sectioneli5-15-1: In one part of the Pacific Ocean, there's a special pathway called the "Ring of Fire." It has lots of volcanoes that are very active and shake the ground with earthquakes. The picture with dots shows where these volcanoes are. It's like a fiery belt around this part of the world! This makes us think about why there are so many volcanoes and what causes them to rumble and grumble so much.
texts.sectioneli5-16-0: When we think about where most volcanoes are, we can imagine looking at a map or picture of the world. Most volcanoes are found in places called the "Ring of Fire," which is a big circle around the Pacific Ocean. This is where the Earth's plates meet and move, causing lots of volcanoes to appear. It's like looking for where the most bubbles are when you stir your bathwater!
texts.sectioneli5-16-1: Imagine Earth is like a giant bumpy ball with some rough and pointy spots called volcanoes. These volcanoes are found all around, but in some parts of the world, there are fewer of them. Think of it as a playground with some areas having lots of slides (volcanoes) and other spots with only a few or none. So, the places with the least volcanoes are like those parts of the playground that are emptier.
texts.sectioneli5-16-2: Volcanoes are usually found in the same places where the Earth's crust has cracks or breaks, like a puzzle. This often happens where the big pieces of the Earth, called tectonic plates, meet or move apart. So, if you look at a map, you'll see volcanoes in long lines or in circles, like the "Ring of Fire" around the Pacific Ocean.
texts.sectioneli5-17-0: The Earth has special patterns we can see on its surface. Earthquakes and volcanoes often happen in long lines between where land meets the ocean. Big mountains are mostly found inside continents or near their edges. We can use maps to see these patterns and understand where they happen.
texts.sectioneli5-17-1: We're going to learn about how the Earth isn't just still and calm. It's like a giant puzzle, and sometimes the pieces move. When they do, we can see things like volcanoes and earthquakes. Volcanoes are like giant mountains that can spill out melted rock, and earthquakes are when the ground shakes because the puzzle pieces are bumping into each other or pulling apart. These changes happen a lot around big oceans like the Pacific Ocean, where the Earth’s puzzle pieces especially like to move and change.
texts.sectioneli5-17-2: Imagine the Earth like a big cracked eggshell. These cracks are called plates, and they move around very slowly. When these plates move a lot, the ground shakes and we get an earthquake. Now, inside the Earth, it’s super hot, like a giant oven. Sometimes, hot melted rock called magma finds a way out through the cracks and becomes a volcano. When a volcano erupts, it’s like a big mountain of melted rock and ash coming out! This also happens a lot around the Pacific Ocean, which is called the ‘Ring of Fire’ because of all the volcanoes and earthquakes there.
texts.sectioneli5-17-3: Volcanoes are like big fizzy soda bottles inside the Earth. When you shake a soda and open it, all the bubbles try to rush out. In a volcano, hot melted rock inside the Earth, like the soda bubbles, wants to come out. So, they push through cracks in the ground. When they come out, they can change how the land looks really fast! This shows that the Earth is like a busy, moving place that never stays the same.
texts.sectioneli5-17-4: Deep inside the Earth, it's really hot, hot enough to melt rocks. These melted rocks find little cracks and come out of the Earth's surface, creating a volcano. Sometimes, a volcano spills out lava like a river, and sometimes it bursts out a lot! Volcanoes can even happen underwater, making big mountains on the ocean floor.
texts.sectioneli5-17-5: Imagine the Earth’s crust, or top layer, like a giant puzzle made of huge pieces called plates. The edges of the Pacific Ocean are like where many of these puzzle pieces meet up. When these pieces move around, sometimes they shake the ground which we call earthquakes, or they can make hot, melted rock burst out, which we call volcanic eruptions. This area is known as the Pacific Ring of Fire, and it's where these exciting changes often happen, like mountains being built or volcanoes erupting.
texts.sectioneli5-18-0:
Imagine the Earth is like a big puzzle made of giant pieces called tectonic plates. The Ring of Fire is a special place where lots of these pieces meet. Sometimes they bump into each other, slide past each other, or move apart. When they do this, they can cause loud rumblings, which we call earthquakes, or create magma that makes volcanoes erupt. It’s kind of like when you wiggle a big block of Jenga pieces, and some parts shake or fall!

The picture shows a red line like a necklace outlining the Ring of Fire where lots of earthquakes and volcanoes happen because of these moving plates. When plates move away from each other, it's like tearing paper; this can make new shapes in the Earth's surface.
texts.sectioneli5-18-1:
Imagine the Earth is like a big puzzle made of giant pieces called tectonic plates. Sometimes, these pieces move and bump into each other along cracks called fault lines. When they do this suddenly, it's like shaking a whole box really hard, making the whole ground around us shake, and that's what we call an earthquake! 

Now, when you knock on a table, you feel and see the vibrations. Similarly, during an earthquake, some waves travel along the ground (these are called surface waves). Others go deeper inside the Earth (these are called body waves). The ones inside make big jerky movements, while the ones on top make the wavy movements. That's why the ground shakes!
texts.sectioneli5-19-0: Imagine the ground is like a big puzzle made of giant pieces called tectonic plates. Sometimes these pieces bump into each other under the Earth. This bumping can push the ground up and make mountains! But, sometimes the ground slips deep below where we can’t see it. And if an earthquake happens in the ocean, it can make a ginormous wave called a tsunami.
texts.sectioneli5-19-1: Imagine the ocean floor is like a giant puzzle made of huge pieces called plates. These plates move and can pull apart in certain places, like at mid-ocean ridges. When they pull apart, it makes room for hot, melted rock called lava to come up and cool down, building new parts of the ocean floor kind of like Lego blocks. When this happens, it can also cause underwater mountains and even earthquakes! The island of Iceland sits right on one of these big ridges, called the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, kind of like sitting on a giant mountain range under the sea.
texts.sectioneli5-20-0:
Imagine the Earth is like a giant jigsaw puzzle. Each piece is a big slab of rock called a plate. These plates float around very slowly on a layer of gooey rock, like icebergs on the ocean. Sometimes, they bump into each other or pull apart, and this happens along lines called boundaries.

Now, when these plates move, they can cause volcanoes to form. A lot of volcanoes are found in a special area called the "Ring of Fire," which is shaped like a horseshoe around the edges of the Pacific Ocean. This is because the edges of many plates meet there.

Sometimes, when the plates shift, they can also cause the ground to shake, which we call an earthquake. So, by looking at where the edges of these plates are, we can guess where we might see volcanoes or earthquakes.

Just like how puzzle pieces change when you move them, the Earth's surface changes too, and that's why making predictions about it is like guessing which piece will move next.
texts.sectioneli5-20-1: The map shows lots of colorful dots that are volcanoes. Most of these dots are in places where you see dark lines, which are like cracks in the Earth's surface called plate boundaries. This means volcanoes usually happen where these big cracks are, like around the edge of the Pacific Ocean in something called the 'Ring of Fire.'
texts.sectioneli5-20-2: The dark lines on the map show where Earth's giant puzzle pieces, called plates, meet. These places are like the edges of the puzzle pieces. When the plates move, they can bump into each other, slide past each other, or move apart, and that's often when earthquakes happen. So, these places with lines are where lots of earthquakes can occur.
texts.sectioneli5-20-3: When Earth's plates move, like puzzle pieces, they can cause volcanoes to erupt or the ground to shake in earthquakes. In the future, this might change the shape of the land, like making mountains taller or forming new islands.
texts.sectioneli5-21-0:
Okay, let's think about two ways the Earth changes! 

First, there's erosion. Imagine sandcastles at the beach slowly getting washed away by the waves—that’s like erosion. Wind and water move tiny bits of rock and soil from one place to another, changing mountains and valleys over a very long time.

Second, think about earthquakes. If you've ever stacked blocks and then the table shakes, the blocks might fall or move. Earthquakes do this to the ground! They happen when parts of the Earth’s crust move suddenly, changing the landscape in an instant. 

So, erosion happens slowly and earthquakes can change things really fast!
texts.sectioneli5-23-0: Imagine all the water on Earth is like a giant bucket. Most of this water, almost the whole bucket, is salty like the ocean. If you had 100 drops of water, 97 of them would taste salty. Only 3 drops out of 100 are freshwater, which is what we need to drink and use every day. This freshwater is mostly trapped in ice or underground, so there's not a lot of it around for us to use easily.
texts.sectioneli5-23-1: Most of Earth's water is salty, like what you find in the ocean, and not for drinking. Only a small amount is fresh, like in lakes and rivers. So, it makes us think about how we use and save the water we can drink. Why do you think it's important to know this? Are you curious about how we get fresh water from all that saltwater?
texts.sectioneli5-24-0: Imagine the Earth like a giant water ball. Most of the water in this ball is salty, like the ocean. Only a little bit of this water is what we can actually use to drink and water plants. If you had a big glass of water, almost all of it would be salty, and only a tiny drop would be the fresh water we need. That's why we have to be careful and smart about using our fresh water!
texts.sectioneli5-25-0: Imagine that Earth is like a giant ball with water everywhere. Some water is salty, like in the oceans, and some is fresh, like in rivers and lakes. We use math, like counting and measuring, to figure out how much salty and fresh water there is. This helps us see where all the water is on Earth, like in icy places and under the ground. It's kind of like figuring out how much juice versus milk is in your fridge!
texts.sectioneli5-25-1: Water on Earth is just about everywhere! It's in the air and clouds above us, which is like a big invisible swimming pool in the sky. It's also in places we can see, like rivers, oceans, and ice. Plus, water is inside plants and animals, and even deep down inside the Earth. So, you could say Earth is a very watery place!
texts.sectioneli5-26-0:
Imagine the Earth is like a big blue marble, mostly covered in water. But most of this water, about 96%, is salty, like what's in the ocean, and we can't drink it. 

Only a tiny bit, about 2.5%, is freshwater, what all living things need to survive. Most of this freshwater is trapped in ice or underground. Just a tiny part of it, 1.2%, is easy to get to, like the water in rivers and lakes. Even though there isn't much of this easy-to-reach freshwater, rivers are really important because they give us water we can actually use every day.
texts.sectioneli5-26-1: Earth has a lot of water, like a big watery blanket! If you imagine the Earth covered in a watery blanket, 71 parts out of 100 are water. Most of this water, about 96 parts out of 100, is in the oceans, which are salty and not for drinking. There's a small bit of water that's fresh, and that's the kind we need to drink and use for plants and animals to live. So, the Earth has a lot of water, but only a tiny bit is the kind we can actually use.
texts.sectioneli5-27-0: You know how when it rains, the water goes into the ground and some of it flows into rivers? Well, even though we see lots of water in rivers and lakes, there’s actually more fresh water hidden underground. This is called groundwater. Imagine it’s like when you pour juice in your sandbox, and it disappears into the sand. That juice is still there, just like water is in the ground. This water is really important because it helps keep rivers full and gives us water to use, especially in places where it's hard to get water otherwise.
texts.sectioneli5-27-1: In 2010, people in the U.S. used lots of water from both lakes and rivers (surface water) and from underground (groundwater). While we usually use surface water for drinking and watering plants, groundwater is also super important. It helps keep lakes and rivers full and supplies water to areas like deserts, where water is hard to find.
texts.sectioneli5-28-0: Imagine all the water on Earth fits in a big bucket. Most of this water, about 97 out of 100 parts, is salty like the ocean. Only a teeny bit, 3 parts out of 100, is freshwater. This freshwater is found mostly in ice and glaciers, underground, and a tiny amount in lakes and rivers. So, even though there's a lot of water on Earth, very little is fresh and can be used for drinking.
texts.sectioneli5-28-1: Most of the water on Earth is salty, like in the oceans. But there is some freshwater too, which we can drink. It's found mostly in three places: icecaps and glaciers (like big ice mountains), in the ground (like water stored underground), and in rivers and lakes (like big natural ponds). These places are important for providing us with the water we need every day.
texts.sectioneli5-28-2: When we look at water on Earth's surface, it's like a giant glass mostly filled with salty ocean water. But a tiny bit of that water is fresh, and this comes from lakes, rivers, and swamps. These are places where we can find usable, fresh water.
texts.sectioneli5-29-0: Your task is to draw a bar graph. This graph will help us compare how much saltwater and freshwater there is on Earth. Imagine two tall rectangles. One shows all the salty ocean water, and the other shows the smaller amount of freshwater, like in rivers and lakes. It's a fun way to see the difference!
texts.easyread-text-10-0: Engineering Design means finding a problem, thinking of solutions, making a plan, building a model, testing it, and fixing any problems.
texts.easyread-text-10-1: Engineers make and change things. They test each new design and then fix it based on what they learn.
texts.easyread-text-10-3: We find out what the problem is. Then, we make simple rules and limits to fix the problem.
texts.easyread-text-10-4: Thinking of ways to fix the problem.
texts.easyread-text-10-5: Engineers think of ideas and work with others to solve problems and make plans.
texts.easyread-text-10-6: Look at different ideas carefully and pick the best one by checking if they follow the rules and meet the needs of the problem.
texts.easyread-text-10-7: Make models and try them out to see if they work.
texts.easyread-text-10-8: The engineer looks at how well new models work according to set rules and limits.
texts.easyread-text-10-9: Help make early models better so they work well.
texts.easyread-text-10-10: Engineering standards in school usually have two kinds of tasks.
texts.easyread-text-10-11: When we design something, we first find the problem. We then think of many ways to fix it, and we choose the best way. We test this idea and make it better.
texts.easyread-text-10-12: When you make a plan, first you have to know what the problem is, what you need, and what you can't do. Then you find the best way to fix it.
texts.easyread-text-10-13: We don't need to think of more solutions because they will be given to us.
texts.easyread-text-10-14: Evaluating means choosing the best answer that fits the rules and needs.
texts.easyread-text-11-1: This section is about the different parts of Earth. Like the air, land, water, and living things that all work together.
texts.easyread-text-11-3: Earth has different shapes on its surface like mountains, rivers, and valleys. These shapes have patterns that we can see and learn about.
texts.easyread-text-11-5: Earth has a lot of water. We find water in oceans, rivers, lakes, and even in the ground.
texts.easyread-text-11-7: Weathering is when rocks break into smaller pieces. Erosion is when water, wind, or ice moves the pieces away.
texts.easyread-text-11-9: Different systems help each other work. They are like friends who play together to finish a game.
texts.easyread-text-11-13: Things are made of matter. Matter can be solid, liquid, or gas. Matter has properties. Properties are things like color, size, and shape. Matter can change. A solid can melt into a liquid. A liquid can freeze into a solid. A liquid can also evaporate into a gas. Changes can happen when we heat or cool things.
texts.easyread-text-11-15: Some things are so tiny that we cannot see them with our eyes.
texts.easyread-text-11-17: Let's learn how to find out what different things are made of.
texts.easyread-text-11-19: When we mix things together, like different ingredients, we can make new stuff.
texts.easyread-text-11-21: The idea of Conservation of Matter says we can't make more matter or make it disappear. If you start with some stuff, you will always have the same amount, even if it changes shape or form.
texts.easyread-text-11-23: Chapter 3 is about how important stuff moves around in Earth's systems.
texts.easyread-text-11-25: This section is about making or growing plants. It is part of a bigger guide.
texts.easyread-text-11-27: Eating means we put food in our mouths, chew it, and swallow it.
texts.easyread-text-11-29: Matter is everything around us. It can be solid, liquid, or gas. Matter can move from one place to another.
texts.easyread-text-11-31: Conserving resources means using things like water and electricity carefully so we don't waste them.
texts.easyread-text-13-1: We will learn how different parts of Earth work and talk to each other.
texts.easyread-text-13-2: A chapter outline is like a list of main ideas or parts in a chapter. It helps you see what the chapter talks about.
texts.easyread-text-13-3: We see patterns in Earth's features like mountains, rivers, and valleys. These patterns help us understand the land better.
texts.easyread-text-13-4: Earth has a lot of water. Water is very important for everything on Earth.
texts.easyread-text-13-5: Weathering means rocks break into small pieces. Erosion means wind and water carry those pieces away.
texts.easyread-text-13-6: Different systems can work together and affect each other.
texts.easyread-text-13-9: The Earth's main parts are land, water, air, and living things.
texts.easyread-text-13-10: These systems talk and work together in many ways.
texts.easyread-text-13-11: Weathering and erosion show how different parts of the Earth work together.
texts.easyread-text-13-12: Some things make landslides, earthquakes, and volcanoes happen. These can be dangerous for people and animals.
texts.easyread-text-13-13: People cannot stop natural disasters, but they can make plans to make them less harmful.
texts.easyread-text-13-8: The picture is by Julius Silver from Pixabay.
texts.easyread-text-15-0: We look for patterns on Earth's surface, like mountains, rivers, and plains, to learn more about them.
texts.easyread-text-15-1: A phenomenon is something that happens and people notice it.
texts.easyread-text-15-2: In the Pacific Ocean, there is a place called the Ring of Fire. This place has a lot of volcanoes and many earthquakes happen there.
texts.easyread-text-15-3: The dots show where active volcanoes are.
texts.easyread-text-15-4: The Ring of Fire is a place with lots of volcanoes. Volcanoes happen because the earth's plates move. When plates touch and push, volcanoes and earthquakes can happen here.
texts.easyread-text-15-5: This is a map of Earth's plate tectonics. The USGS made it, and you can see it online at Wikimedia Commons.
texts.easyread-text-15-6: Observations are things you see or notice. Wonderings are things you think about or are curious about.
texts.easyread-text-15-7: What can you see happening? Tell me what you notice about what is going on.
texts.easyread-text-15-8: What do you want to know about this thing?
texts.easyread-text-16-0: Focus questions are special questions that help you find important details.
texts.easyread-text-16-1: You see the most volcanoes in places where the Earth's plates meet, like the Ring of Fire around the Pacific Ocean.
texts.easyread-text-16-2: You can see the most volcanoes near the ocean and in some mountains.
texts.easyread-text-16-3: You don't see many volcanoes in places that are not near the edges of Earth's plates, like in the middle of big continents.
texts.easyread-text-16-5: Active volcanoes are often in groups or lines near the edges of continents, along mountain ranges, or on islands. They are usually found in places where the Earth's plates meet.
texts.easyread-text-17-0: We see patterns like mountains, rivers, and valleys on Earth. These patterns show us how the land is shaped.
texts.easyread-text-17-1: Look at the pictures and find patterns of Earth's features, like mountains and rivers.
texts.easyread-text-17-2: Earthquakes and volcanoes usually happen where land meets the ocean. Big mountains are inside continents or near the edges.
texts.easyread-text-17-3: Maps can show where mountains are, where the ocean floor is, and where volcanoes and earthquakes happen.
texts.easyread-text-17-5: In this chapter, you will learn about different shapes and things we see on Earth's surface.
texts.easyread-text-17-6: Volcanoes, Earthquakes, and Ocean Floor: How Earth Changes
texts.easyread-text-17-7: A volcano is a mountain that can blow out hot rocks and lava from inside the earth.
texts.easyread-text-17-8: Volcanoes are holes in the ground. They let out hot, melted rocks, ash, and gases.
texts.easyread-text-17-9: Volcanoes can quickly change the Earth's surface.
texts.easyread-text-17-10: More than half of Earth's ground has volcanic rock.
texts.easyread-text-17-11: Volcanoes show us that the Earth is alive and always changing.
texts.easyread-text-17-12: A volcano forms when hot, melted rock called magma pushes up from deep inside the Earth and comes out through holes in the ground.
texts.easyread-text-17-13: Deep underground, it is so hot that rocks can melt.
texts.easyread-text-17-14: Hot, melted rock comes out from cracks in the ground and makes a volcano.
texts.easyread-text-17-15: Some volcanoes send out rivers of lava. Other volcanoes erupt even bigger.
texts.easyread-text-17-16: Volcanoes can explode under the sea and make big mountains called volcanic mountains on the ocean floor.
texts.easyread-text-17-17: The Pacific Ring of Fire is an area around the edges of the Pacific Ocean. Here, there are many volcanoes and earthquakes that happen often.
texts.easyread-text-17-18: Most earthquakes and volcanoes happen near the Pacific Ocean's edges.
texts.easyread-text-17-19: The Earth's outer layer is made of big pieces that fit together like a puzzle.
texts.easyread-text-17-20: Moving plates can cause big changes like earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountains.
texts.easyread-text-18-0: There are many volcanoes and earthquakes in the Ring of Fire because the ground moves a lot there.
texts.easyread-text-18-1: In the Ring of Fire, pieces of Earth's crust move on top of each other.
texts.easyread-text-18-2: Hot melted rock under the ground makes volcanoes erupt.
texts.easyread-text-18-3: The Pacific Plate and North American Plate move sideways past each other.
texts.easyread-text-18-4: Some places in the ground shake a lot because the ground moves and then stops.
texts.easyread-text-18-17: There is a map of the Pacific Ring of Fire on Wikipedia. Anyone can use it because it is in the public domain.
texts.easyread-text-18-5: Big pieces of the Earth's crust can slowly move apart from each other on land.
texts.easyread-text-18-6: Continental rifting is when a big piece of land splits apart slowly.
texts.easyread-text-18-7: When this happens, the crust gets thinner, cracks, and then separates.
texts.easyread-text-18-8: Earthquakes are when the ground shakes because the Earth's pieces move.
texts.easyread-text-18-9: Earthquakes happen when big pieces of the Earth's surface move suddenly. This makes the ground shake.
texts.easyread-text-18-10: When big shakes happen, they can change the land quickly and a lot.
texts.easyread-text-18-11: Big pressures build up under the Earth's surface. These pressures are released in waves along a crack.
texts.easyread-text-18-12: The ground moves and makes waves.
texts.easyread-text-18-13: Some waves move along the ground. We call these surface waves.
texts.easyread-text-18-14: Body waves are special waves that move inside the Earth.
texts.easyread-text-18-15: In an earthquake, special waves make the ground shake hard.
texts.easyread-text-18-16: Surface waves cause changes we can see on the ground.
texts.easyread-text-19-0: Rolling movements cause a lot of harm.
texts.easyread-text-19-1: Earthquakes can change the shape of the land.
texts.easyread-text-19-2: When an earthquake happens, the ground shakes, and the land can rise up to make mountains.
texts.easyread-text-19-3: Sometimes, when an earthquake happens, it doesn't leave any marks on the surface because it happens deep inside the Earth.
texts.easyread-text-19-4: Earthquakes in the ocean can cause a big wave called a tsunami.
texts.easyread-text-19-5: The ocean floor is the bottom of the sea. It has sand, rocks, and plants. Many fish and strange animals live there. It's dark and quiet at the ocean floor.
texts.easyread-text-19-6: In the ocean, plates move away from each other at certain places. This makes space for hot, melted rock called lava to come up and form volcanoes.
texts.easyread-text-19-7: When lava comes out, it moves the old seafloor and makes new ground in the ocean.
texts.easyread-text-19-8: There are mountains under the ocean.
texts.easyread-text-19-9: When parts of the Earth's surface move away from each other, the ground shakes.
texts.easyread-text-19-10: Most mountains under the ocean are deep underwater.
texts.easyread-text-19-11: Iceland is on top of a big underwater mountain range in the Atlantic Ocean.
texts.easyread-text-19-12: "Mid Atlantic Ridge" by Mangwanani is a work that everyone can use.
texts.easyread-text-19-13: The rift valley in Iceland is on a big line called the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
texts.easyread-text-20-2: This is an image made by the USGS. You can use it because it is free to share and use.
texts.easyread-text-20-4: The dots show where the active volcanoes are.
texts.easyread-text-20-6: The dark lines show where Earth's plates meet.
texts.easyread-text-20-7: Plate boundaries are where big pieces of the Earth meet and move. When they move, it can cause earthquakes.
texts.easyread-text-20-3: Focus questions help you learn by pointing the way.
texts.easyread-text-20-8: Volcanoes are mountains that can throw out hot melted rock, ash, and gas from inside the Earth. Earthquakes happen when the ground shakes because the Earth moves under us.
texts.easyread-text-20-9: In the future, Earth's surface might change because of more storms, melting ice raising sea levels, and earthquakes. These can change the ground and water around us.
texts.easyread-text-21-0: I need the text to simplify for children with learning disabilities.
texts.easyread-text-21-1: Wind and rain wear down rocks to make mountains smaller. This is called erosion. In other places, the ground shakes and can crack. This is an earthquake.
texts.easyread-text-23-0: Earth has a lot of water. Water is in oceans, rivers, lakes, and even in the ground. We need water to drink, wash, and grow food. Water is very important for life.
texts.easyread-text-23-1: Phenomenon means something amazing that you can see or feel.
texts.easyread-text-23-2: Most of the water on Earth is salty. It is not fresh.
texts.easyread-text-23-16: Almost all water on Earth is salty. Only a little bit of water is not salty and is called freshwater.
texts.easyread-text-23-3: Saltwater has salt in it, like the water in the ocean. Freshwater does not have salt, like the water in lakes and rivers.
texts.easyread-text-23-4: Earth has a lot of water. Most of it is salty ocean water. Only a little bit is fresh water that we can use.
texts.easyread-text-23-5: 97% is a big number, which means almost everything. If something is 97%, it means only a little bit is missing.
texts.easyread-text-23-8: Fresh water is water that we can drink. It is found in lakes and rivers. Animals, plants, and people need fresh water to live.
texts.easyread-text-23-9: 68.7 out of every 100 is about icecaps and glaciers.
texts.easyread-text-23-10: About 30% of the water found under the ground.
texts.easyread-text-23-12: Surface water is the water we see in rivers, lakes, and oceans.
texts.easyread-text-23-13: About 87% of something is connected to lakes.
texts.easyread-text-23-14: 11% of the area is covered with swampy, wet land.
texts.easyread-text-23-15: Rivers are only a small part, like 2%, of something bigger.
texts.easyread-text-23-18: Things I see and things I think about.
texts.easyread-text-23-19: What do you see happening here?
texts.easyread-text-23-20: 2. What do you want to know about this thing?
texts.easyread-text-24-0: These are important questions to think about.
texts.easyread-text-24-1: Most of the water on Earth is salty. It is in the oceans.
texts.easyread-text-24-2: Only a small amount of the water on Earth is in lakes, swamps, or rivers.
texts.easyread-text-24-3: This question might be hard because it asks for complex thinking. We can simplify by asking, 'Did you see anything unexpected in the data?'
texts.easyread-text-25-0: Earth has a lot of water. The ocean has salty water. Rivers and lakes have fresh water. We drink fresh water.
texts.easyread-text-25-1: We use counting and computers to see how much saltwater and freshwater there are in different places on Earth. This helps us know where most of the water is.
texts.easyread-text-25-2: Think about big water places we know about: oceans, lakes, rivers, glaciers are like frozen rivers, water in the ground called groundwater, and really cold places with lots of ice called polar ice caps.
texts.easyread-text-25-5: This is about how much saltwater and freshwater is on Earth. Saltwater is much more than freshwater.
texts.easyread-text-25-3: People use math by measuring, estimating, making graphs, or finding percentages.
texts.easyread-text-25-6: Most of Earth's water is in the oceans. Some water is in rivers, lakes, and underground. Water is also in the air and in living things like plants and animals.
texts.easyread-text-25-7: Water is almost everywhere on Earth.
texts.easyread-text-25-8: Above us, there is air and clouds.
texts.easyread-text-25-9: Water on Earth is in rivers, oceans, and ice.
texts.easyread-text-25-10: Plants are living things that grow on Earth.
texts.easyread-text-25-11: Inside the Earth, there are rocks and dirt, and this part is called the geosphere.
texts.easyread-text-26-6: Most of Earth's water is in the oceans. Some water is in ice and snow on mountains and the North and South Poles. We also find water in rivers, lakes, and underground. A little water is in the air as clouds and vapor.
texts.easyread-text-26-0: The chart shows where we find water on Earth and how much there is in different places.
texts.easyread-text-26-1: Only 2.5% of Earth's water is freshwater that we need to stay alive.
texts.easyread-text-26-2: Most freshwater is in ice and underground. Only a small part, just over 1.2%, is surface water. This surface water is what we mostly use for our needs.
texts.easyread-text-26-3: Most surface freshwater is in ice. Another 20.9% is in lakes.
texts.easyread-text-26-4: Rivers are a small part of Earth's fresh water.
texts.easyread-text-26-5: Rivers do not hold much freshwater, but they give us most of the water we can use.
texts.easyread-text-26-23: The book "Water in Crisis" talks about fresh water in the world and was edited by Peter Gleick in 1993.
texts.easyread-text-26-24: There is a lot of water on Earth. It's in oceans, rivers, lakes, underground, and even in the air.
texts.easyread-text-26-25: The Earth has a lot of water. How much water is there on Earth?
texts.easyread-text-26-26: Most of the Earth is covered in water, about 71 out of every 100 parts. The oceans have most of this water, around 96 out of every 100 parts.
texts.easyread-text-26-27: Water can be in many places like rivers, lakes, or even in the air as clouds.
texts.easyread-text-27-1: Freshwater is clean water that we find in rivers, lakes, and streams. It is not salty like the ocean.
texts.easyread-text-27-0: Water can be found in the air as vapor, in rivers and lakes, frozen in ice caps and glaciers, and in the ground as wet soil.
texts.easyread-text-27-2: There is a lot of water underground, more than what you see on Earth's surface.
texts.easyread-text-27-3: Some of the water in rivers comes from the ground.
texts.easyread-text-27-4: Rainwater goes into the ground and fills places underground where we keep water.
texts.easyread-text-27-5: Water in the ground slowly moves into rivers.
texts.easyread-text-27-6: People use water from rivers and lakes, and also water from under the ground.
texts.easyread-text-27-7: In 2010, people in the United States used a lot of water every day from lakes and rivers.
texts.easyread-text-27-8: People use a lot of groundwater every day. It is about 79 billion gallons each day.
texts.easyread-text-27-9: People often use surface water for drinking and watering plants.
texts.easyread-text-27-10: Groundwater is important. It helps fill rivers and lakes. It gives water to people in dry places.
texts.easyread-text-27-11: like in towns in the hot, dry parts of the western United States.
texts.easyread-text-28-0: Putting It Together means making all the parts fit or organizing everything to work.
texts.easyread-text-28-1: Saltwater is in the ocean and has salt. Freshwater is in rivers and lakes and has no salt.
texts.easyread-text-28-6: Fresh water is clean water we can drink. It does not have salt, like sea water.
texts.easyread-text-28-21: Almost all of Earth's water is salty, like ocean water. Only a tiny bit is fresh water that we can drink.
texts.easyread-text-28-22: A person named Mariana Ruiz Villarreal, also known as LadyofHats, made an image for the CK-12 Foundation. You can use this image if you follow the rules in its CC BY-NC 3.0 license.
texts.easyread-text-28-24: Freshwater is found in lakes, rivers, and glaciers.
texts.easyread-text-28-23: Focus questions are important questions that help us learn and understand better.
texts.easyread-text-28-25: Rivers, lakes, ponds, streams, and reservoirs contribute to Earth's surface water.
texts.easyread-text-29-1: We have more salt water than freshwater on Earth. Let's imagine a picture. One tall bar shows salt water. A short bar shows freshwater. The tall bar is much bigger.
